content: The Act titled "Identity Theft and Assumption Deterrence Act of 1998" is based on Congress's authority to regulate commerce and make necessary laws. It addresses the issue of identity theft. The Act "Identity Theft and Assumption Deterrence Act of 1998" amends Section 1028(a) of title 18, United States Code to include knowingly transferring or using another person's identification without lawful authority to commit unlawful activities. Penalties under Section 1028(b) are also amended. The Act "Identity Theft and Assumption Deterrence Act of 1998" expands penalties under Section 1028(b) of title 18, United States Code for offenses involving the transfer or use of means of identification resulting in obtaining $1,000 or more in value during a 1-year period. The Act "Identity Theft and Assumption Deterrence Act of 1998" expands penalties under Section 1028(b) of title 18, United States Code for offenses involving the transfer, use, or means of identification, resulting in obtaining $1,000 or more in value during a 1-year period. Amendments include increasing penalties to up to 20 years imprisonment for offenses related to drug trafficking, violent crimes, or repeat offenses. Definitions in the Act clarify terms like "document-making implement" and "identification document." The term 'identification document' refers to a document authorized by the government or international organization for identifying individuals. 'Means of identification' includes names, numbers, and official IDs like social security numbers and driver's licenses. The term 'personal identification card' refers to an ID issued by a government for identification purposes, including unique biometric and electronic data. The term 'personal identification card' is defined as an ID issued by a State or local government solely for identification purposes. Additionally, the term 'produce' includes altering, authenticating, or assembling documents. The term 'State' encompasses all states of the United States, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, and other U.S. territories. Amendments are made to Section 1028 of title 18, United States Code regarding attempt and conspiracy offenses. Amendments to Section 1028 of title 18, United States Code include penalties for attempting or conspiring to commit offenses, forfeiture procedures governed by the Comprehensive Drug Abuse Prevention and Control Act, and a rule of construction for identification documents. The rule of construction clarifies that a single identification document containing multiple means of identification is considered as one means of identification. Conforming amendments are made to Chapter 47 of title 18, United States Code to reflect these changes. SEC. 4. AMENDMENT OF FEDERAL SENTENCING GUIDELINES FOR OFFENSES UNDER SECTION 1028. The United States Sentencing Commission will review and amend the Federal sentencing guidelines to establish appropriate penalties for offenses under section 1028 of title 18, United States Code. Factors for consideration include the number of victims and means of identification involved in the offense. The Federal sentencing guidelines will consider factors such as harm caused by the offense, number of means of identification involved, value of loss to individuals, range of conduct covered, and sentencing enhancements. The Federal sentencing guidelines consider factors such as harm caused by the offense, number of means of identification involved, value of loss to individuals, range of conduct covered, sentencing enhancements, achieving sentencing purposes, and any other relevant factors deemed appropriate by the United States Sentencing Commission. SEC. 5. CENTRALIZED COMPLAINT AND CONSUMER EDUCATION SERVICE FOR VICTIMS OF IDENTITY THEFT. The Federal Trade Commission will establish procedures within a year of this Act to log complaints from individuals who believe their identification has been stolen, provide information to these individuals, and refer complaints to relevant entities including consumer reporting agencies and law enforcement for potential action. The Federal Trade Commission will refer complaints of identity theft to consumer reporting agencies and law enforcement for potential action. Authorization of appropriations is provided for carrying out this section. SEC. 6. Technical amendments to Title 18, United States Code include a correction related to criminal forfeiture procedures and the inclusion of economic espionage and theft of trade secrets as predicate offenses for wire interception. SEC. 7. Redaction of ethics reports filed by judicial officers and employees. Section 105(b) of the Ethics in Government Act of 1978 is amended to allow for redaction of reports filed by certain individuals if revealing personal information could endanger them. The Judicial Conference, in consultation with the United States Marshall Service, can make this determination. The redaction is only allowed to the extent necessary to protect the individual and as long as the danger exists. The Administrative Office of the United States Courts must submit an annual report to the Committees on the Judiciary regarding the operation of this provision. The Administrative Office of the United States Courts must submit an annual report to the Committees on the Judiciary regarding the total number of reports redacted, individuals affected, and types of threats. The Judicial Conference, in consultation with the Department of Justice, will issue regulations on redaction circumstances and procedures. This provision expires on December 31, 2001.
